subject: Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit	in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: ... I know of few TDD proponents that don t do some modicum of up-front design. The amount I ve found I need to do is small, and a lot of it is in my head.
messageBody:
Quoting CÃ©dric Beust ? <cbeust@...>:
> I would also point out that the term "Test-Driven Design" strongly seems to
> imply that your tests drive your design. Which is what I was objecting
> against, and also why I much prefer calling it "Test-Driven Development"
> (and I still think that it's something you should do whenever you can but
> you certainly don't need to do it 100% of the time to obtain well-tested
> code).

I know of few TDD proponents that don't do some modicum of up-front
design. The amount I've found I need to do is small, and a lot of it
is in my head. What most of us rail against is the notion that we need
to produce a complete, highly detailed up-front design.

You're incorrectly assuming that TDD is just about testing, or even
testing+design, which its proponents suggest. Not considering its
impact on improving how to approach design (which can feed back in the
ability to improve upon up-front design), if that's all we got out of
it, TDDing 100% of the time would seem to be reasonably expensive.
Particularly for someone who was very good at designing, like yourself.

We also do a lot of "after the fact" design, i.e. we're continually
trying to stay cognizant of the design impacts of every few lines of
code. We try to do something about it, as opposed to the crowd that
presumes their up-front design is perfect.

The bigger thing TDD does is enable refactoring of code. Whether or
not the design up front was good, the most significant costs lie in
the implementation and extended maintenance of the system. If you ever
get a chance to work on systems that are more than a couple years old,
and where business demands keep coming, you'll find that's where the
true costs are. Most code out there is just bad, and highly, highly
redundant.

Unfortunately, it's very dangerous for programmers to start guessing
where they don't need tests, particularly if they're not as highly
skilled as you obviously are. They usually guess wrong. Laziness tends
to take control of this guessing game, and not enough tests get
written. Maybe that's not so bad, if we have enough integration tests
(most systems rarely do). But the bigger impact is that lack of tests
significantly increases the risk of keeping the code clean, and the
system takes a much quicker route to complete degradation.

Try working on a C++ system like this that's been around 10 years,
that takes an hour just to build, and for which it takes hours to
figure out where a simple chunk of code goes, and hours or days more
to figure out whether or not you've broken something by making your
simple change. Sweetly, and with great karma, the defects often crop
up in the untested areas, where we thought we were too smart to have
needed tests.

I also get a lot of value out of tests that programmers crafted with
the intent to help me understand what the classes are about. I've had
opportunities to work with systems that were comprehensively covered
with unit tests. It's a breeze to find what you're looking for in such
a system, as opposed to the typical nightmare of navigating through a
system in which no one considers the value that clean tests can
create, and for which only poor, out-of-date written documents exist.

If you're sold on the value of your level of investment in TDD, fine.
Others have gotten far more out of it.

Jeff Langr
